titleStmt.title: Letter to General Edward Sabine
Letter to General Edward Sabine, 19 December 1858
titleStmt.author: Livingstone, David, 1813-1873

publicationStmt.publisher: Wellcome Centre for the History of Medicine, UCL

revisionDesc.change: 2007-06-20 Sharon MessengerInitial Transcription by Sharon Messenger

div.p:
In transmitting this
first installmentinstalment of observations
to your care I have to regret that
Mr Baines was unable from the
effects of a slight sun stroke to repeat
them. He is however now almost
well and will be in order to take
a complete set at Tette. Mr Livingstone
will repeat his probably on both
sides of the river.

I have also to beg your
aid in procuring another spirit
level as per enclosed pencil sketch.
It was broken probably when a
portion of the roof of our house
was blown away & the servants
removed our luggage from one
end of the dwelling to the other.
Tthe level itself is enclosed among
some sketches sent to the Foreign
Office. The part of the instruments
to which this belongs was not
sent to Kew for examination
and was so badly constructed as
to give us a world of trouble
adjusting it. An upright glass tube
which is required to be quite
perpendicular is screwed into wood
only & the thread yields either way
to the brass. The socket ought
clearly to have been brass. Any
hints you may have to offer
after examining the observations
will be thankfully recievedreceived.

Tthe new level may be sent
to the care of Admiral Grey
at the Cape but should
H. M. Government decide
on sending out a vessel of
greater power than we at present
possess to ascend the rapids
of Kebra basa that may be
the safest conveyance.
